label: Task-16
title: Create shareable workflow document for agentic role-based development setup

properties.description: Create a single, self-contained document that explains the current agentic development workflow used in the Issues-FS ecosystem. This document will be used as a template/guide for setting up similar agentic workflows on OTHER projects. It must be written to be project-agnostic and NOT dependent on a multi-repo architecture.
requirements: MUST be a single document (not spread across multiple files)
MUST be project-agnostic — explain the pattern, not Issues-FS specifics
MUST NOT assume multi-repo / submodule architecture — the target project is smaller and uses a single repo
MUST be usable as a starting point for a new project with a similar agentic setup
content_to_cover: The role-based agent coordination model (Conductor, Architect, Dev, QA, DevOps, Librarian + extensible)
How ROLE.md files work as both human documentation AND agent briefing
The hub-and-spoke subagent pattern (parent Conductor spawns role-specific agents)
How Issues-FS (or any file-based issue tracker) serves as the coordination bus between agents
The typed issue state machine (Task, Handoff, Decision, Defect, Approval, Knowledge_Request, etc.)
How agents communicate via issues and file artifacts (not direct messaging)
The review workflow: Architect plans -> Dev executes -> QA reviews -> Conductor approves
How LLM guidance docs (briefs, coding standards) ground agent behaviour
The task lifecycle: todo -> in-progress -> done, with dev_notes and comments
Code comment traceability (referencing issue labels in code)
How to adapt this to a single-repo project (roles/ as folders, not separate repos)
Lessons learned: what worked, what didn't, what to watch for (e.g. type safety regressions, agent context limits, background agent timeouts)
source_material: The current Claude Code session transcript (this is a living example of the workflow in action)
properties.notes: This is high priority — the project owner needs this for a new project they are starting. The document should be practical and actionable, not theoretical. Think of it as a 'getting started guide for agentic development' that someone could follow to set up their own role-based AI agent team on any project.
